thread.title: Taoiseach Enda Kenny says poll will be next Spring or it could be November
thread.title_full: Taoiseach Enda Kenny says poll will be next Spring or it could be November

author: Pat Flanagan
title: Taoiseach Enda Kenny says poll will be next Spring or it could be November
text:
Taoiseach Enda Kenny says poll will be next Spring or it could be November 17:12, 11 Oct 2015 Enda Kenny said he intends to let the Government run its full term, which would mean an election in early February or early March Share   Collins Photo Agency Taoiseach Enda Kenny TD at the Office opening and company expansion announcement by Workday at Kings Buidlings, Dublin. Photo: Gareth Chaney Collins 
The general election will take place next year, the Taoiseach insisted yesterday - while refusing to rule out going to the polls in November. 
Enda Kenny said he intends to let the Government run its full term, which would mean an election in early February or early March. 
He said: “Well I haven’t changed my mind, I’ve been very consistent in anything I’ve said about this. 
“My intention is to have the General Election in the Spring of 2016, and I see no reason to change that.” 
But the Fine Gael leader has been anything but consistent and last week refused to rule out a pre-Christmas election on four separate occasions - causing strains with its Labour coalition partners. 
And while Mr Kenny yesterday appeared to clear up the confusion by insisting the election would be in the Spring, his wording “I see no reason to change my mind” could mean he might change his mind if circumstances change. 
His refusal to end the speculation has threatened to undermine trust between the Coalition parties, with one Labour TD claiming he would not support another voting pact with Fine Gael if the Taoiseach called a snap election. 
But yesterday, Mr Kenny said it was crucial for both parties to head into the election on a joint platform. 
He told RTE’s Week in Politics: “The important thing is both parties, Fine Gael and Labour, go into this election on a joint electoral pact platform. Yes we will have different programmes.” 
Fianna Fáil said it was difficult to take the Taoiseach seriously, as party leader Micheal Martin claimed it was Enda Kenny who fuelled uncertainty during the week by deliberately dodging questions in the Dáil. 
He said: “The Taoiseach has only himself to blame for the political uncertainty created on the timing of the election. 
“It’s clear from the Taoiseach’s comments today that the election will be next year. However the country did not need to be treated to an unedifying spectacle this week of Labour Ministers and TDs appearing desperate to stay in government and Fine Gael representatives leaving the door open to a snap election after the budget for their own political expediency. 
“I asked the Taoiseach very straightforward questions on this and other matters related to the Banking Inquiry report on Tuesday and Wednesday and his decision to dodge and to fudge the issue shows his contempt for the Dáil and actually fuelled the uncertainty over the timing of the election. 
“It’s difficult to take the Taoiseach seriously when he said he ‘never changed his mind’ on the timing of the election. He has been forced into a humiliating climb-down today.” Previous Articles
